content: How can I help you today?

I've just been so stressed lately. Work has been tough, and I can't stop these racing thoughts at night. I’m terrified of losing my job, and it’s affecting everything—my sleep, my mood, and how I show up for my family. I don’t even know if talking about this is going to help, to be honest.

It sounds like this has been a really heavy time for you. Work pressures, racing thoughts, and worry about your family are all piling up, and it’s leaving you feeling overwhelmed. Just being here and sharing this shows a lot of courage. What’s been on your mind most about all this?

Honestly, the thought of losing my job is what keeps me up the most. If I get fired, I don’t know how I’ll pay the bills or take care of my family. It’s like this constant spiral in my head, and I don’t know how to make it stop.

It sounds like the fear of losing your job is weighing heavily on you, and it feels like it’s leading to a cycle of worry that’s hard to break. It makes sense how that would bring so much stress, especially when it ties directly to providing for your family. What impact has all of this been having on how you’re feeling day to day?

Honestly, it’s exhausting. I feel drained all the time, and it’s starting to make me irritable, even with my partner and kids. I hate that I can’t just shut my brain off and be more present with them. The stress feels like it’s everywhere.

You’re really carrying a lot right now, and the exhaustion and irritability make it hard to be the way you want with your family. It sounds like there’s a part of you that deeply values your connection with them, yet the weight of your stress is pulling you away from that. How do you wish things could be different for you right now?

I wish I could stop worrying all the time and just feel normal again. I want to be able to sleep, have energy, and be more patient and present with my family. I just want to feel like I’m in control of things instead of things controlling me.

It’s clear how much you want to regain that sense of balance and control in your life, both for yourself and for your family. That desire to feel more at peace and fully present shows how deeply you care. What small steps do you think might help you ease into feeling more like the person you want to be?
I honestly don’t know. I’ve been so stuck in my head that I wouldn’t even know where to start. It just feels like everything is piling up, and I can’t catch a break.

Feeling stuck like this can make it really hard to see a way forward, especially when everything seems overwhelming. Would it help to take a step back and look at one area—like sleep, mood, or even daily routines—where making a small change might bring even a little relief? That could be a starting point to ease some of the tension. Is there one area like that you'd want to focus on?

I guess sleep would be a good place to start. If I could actually rest, maybe I wouldn't feel so drained all the time, and it might help clear my head a little. But I just don’t know how to stop my mind from racing when I’m trying to sleep.

Focusing on sleep is a thoughtful starting point, and the idea of easing your mind could bring you closer to getting the rest you need. It’s challenging when racing thoughts take over, but even small steps can sometimes make a difference. Would you be open to exploring what triggers your thoughts at night or experimenting with ways to calm them?

I suppose I could try. It’s usually work stuff that gets to me the most—thinking about what I didn’t finish, what might go wrong, or how to deal with my boss. If you have suggestions for how to quiet that down, I’m willing to listen.

Thank you for being open to exploring this. It sounds like the demands of work are a big part of those nighttime racing thoughts. There might be ways to help settle your mind, but before diving into suggestions, is it okay to take a closer look together at how these thoughts connect with your overall stress or even your routines before bed?

Sure, I can try that. Before bed, I usually just go over everything in my head and stress about what’s coming tomorrow. I might scroll through my phone to distract myself, but it doesn’t seem to help much. If you think there’s a better routine I could try, I’m willing to hear it.

It’s understandable that you turn to your phone as a distraction when those thoughts feel overwhelming, even if it hasn’t been helping as much as you’d like. Would it be helpful to explore different ways to shift your mind or settle before bed, or is there anything you’ve tried in the past that made even a small difference in calming yourself?

It’s understandable that you turn to your phone as a distraction when those thoughts feel overwhelming, even if it hasn’t been helping as much as you’d like. Maybe we could try some small adjustments to your bedtime routine—like setting aside work thoughts earlier in the evening by writing them down or trying a relaxing activity instead of scrolling. How would you feel about experimenting with those ideas?

It sounds like you're looking for steps that might bring a sense of calm before bed. Writing down your work thoughts earlier or swapping scrolling for something soothing could be worth considering. Could starting with one small change feel manageable, and if so, which idea feels most realistic for you to try?
I think writing my thoughts down earlier in the evening might help. Maybe it would get some of the stress out of my head before I try to sleep. I can give it a shot and see if it helps even a little.

That sounds like a meaningful step—getting those thoughts out of your head and onto paper could create a bit of space for calm before bed. It’s a small but intentional effort, and it shows your willingness to try and regain some control over your evenings. Would you want to set a specific time for this or keep it flexible to see what works for you?
